Pres. Muller
Pleased With
New WJHU

MSE Inadequacies
Impede Research

University President Steven
Muller said Tuesday that he
was "quite pleased" with the
expansion of WJHU, the
Hopkins FM radio station
which boosted power from 10
watts to 10,000 watts early
Tuesday morning, but added,
"If there is any mistake [for the
two year delay in the power
boost] it was my mistake."
Muller originally told the
Hopkins community in the
spring of 1984 that the station
would boost power within three
months. Commenting on that
prediction on Tuesday, he said,
"I misspoke out of naivite."
Muller added, "I am no
engineer, and I don't know a
damned thing about broadcasting."
Speaking in a wide-ranging
interview, Muller also commented on the last-minute delays
that have hampered attempts to
have the expanded station on
the air before the return of
classes this year. Since the end
of August, WJHU has been
ready to expand to 10,000 watts
but received official F.C.C.
permission to do so only this
week.
Muller said, "I am disappointed that we weren't on the
air at the beginning of the
semester. I assume that this was
not a big deal for the F.C.C....
I do not believe it was an act of
ill will."

"This chain of political intolerance on campus doesn't
seem to be getting any better,"
commented Gail Evans, a
member of the Coalition for a
Free South Africa, in response
to the destruction of one of the
newly-erected pro-divestment
shanties Monday night on the
Lower Quad.
According to Evans, two
males were allegedly seen fleeing the scene at about 11 p.m.
on Monday by Coalition
member Michael Johns. Dean
of Students Chris Colombo
verified that at about 11:20
p.m. the University switchboard received two calls, one
from a custodian and another
from a student, alerting
Homewood Security that. the
shanty had been demolished.

Evans said that Colombo
and Vice President for Institutional Affairs Joseph "Jakie"
Hall had promised that the
University would conduct a full
investigation of the incident.
"We're trying to piece the facts
together," said Colombo. "I
don't know how much we can
put together."
Colombo acknowledged that
security has been stepped up on
the Lower Quad as a result of
the incident.
Evans added that someone
attempted to remove the
plywood remains on Wednesday, but was prevented from
doing so by Hall. The Coalition
has asked University President
Steven Muller to release a formal statement on the incident,
via a letter to the News-Letter

and Gazette.
"We're just continually
amazed that people are annoyed by this [shanty protest],"
explained Evans.
The Coalition has scheduled
a rally today at noon, during
which a new shanty will be constructed. Evans said that the
remnants of the destroyed
shanty will remain on the Quad
as a reminder of intolerance,
Informal speeches addressing
the role of shanties as symbolic
speech will be featured at the
"Bop 'Til Apartheid Drops"
dance tonight at 9 p.m. in the
Great Hall.

BEST MEN'S HAIRCUT
BALTIMORE CITY PAPER
These days you're going to get the
cheapest men's haircut at one of
those chain-cutteries and we find
nothing wrong with that. But we
prefer, if we're going to get our
hair cut at a moderate price, to
channel our money into a small
business, closely held and without a
lot of overhead for fancy "atmosphere," advertising, and corporate superstructure. So we go to
Hair Unlimited. This tiny studio,
tucked away in the basement of a
white-stucco apartment building,
certainly has low overhead, but
your hair looks great once you
climb back to street level. The proprietor, Ellen Gifford, has been
cutting for 12 years and has owned
this shop for more than half that
time. She has a steady, experienced
hand, and tells the best jokes we've
ever heard in the chair.

Risque Poster Draws 7 Official Complaints
by L. M. Asia
Karla Steffens, a graduate
student in the Writing Seminars
department, sees the recent
uproar over a poetry and fiction reading poster to he "one
particular incident highlighting
problems on the Hopkins campus involving tolerance and free
expression."
Steffens and David Kellogg,
advertising a Graduate Reading
Series program, postered
Oilman Hall on Friday, October 3 with a black and white,
legal-sized poster of an antique
Japanese print depicting a
woman engaged in oral sex with
an octopus.
The poster was met with
seven official complaints, two
of which were by deans, according to Professor Bob Arellano
of the Writing Seminars Department. The complaints were
sent through Affirmative Action as required by federal law
according to Matthew Crenson,
Associate Dean of Arts and
Sciences.
Steffens said that AreIlan°
asked for the removal of the
posters Monday morning, October 6. There were no such
posters left to be removed, said
Steffens, attributing their
removal to the same person
who had lodged the initial complaint. Steffens had offered to
black out the reference to the
Writing Seminars Department
but this was unacceptable to
AreIlano, she said. She added
that the incident was one where
"Writing Seminars could have
stood behind its own and
didn't."
Crenson met with Steffens
that Monday morning. Crenson, not "wanting to second
guess" the Writing Seminars
Department, stated that "a
number of people had complained" and "requested a
statement in the light of free expression" of Steffens' purposei
and reason for using the print
on the poster. It was not meant,
said Crenson, as "punishment
or judicial action." Crenson
said he saw it instead as a
opportunity for
"good
dialogue" and a "case for
and
general
principles
guidelines" for the newlyformed faculty commission,
chaired by Dr. Richard E.
Flathman of the Political
Science Department, to recommend guidelines for freedom of
expression on the Homewood
campus.
Steffens agreed io withhold
the right to reposter, she said
because she wanted the commission to address the case. A
second poster was issued which
illustrated a print of the first
cover of Ms. magazine showing
a woman with eight arms each
holding a typewriter, frying
pan, feather duster, clock,
telephone, mirror, steering
wheel, and iron, respectively.
There is a baby superimposed
over the woman's stomach.
Steffens
called
the
Homewood campus a "straight
place" with a "definite intolerance for what someone
deems provocative, labeling it
sexist, pornographic and an

eyesore." The population here
"sees and reacts, not participating, but just as an audience" said Steffens. In the
original poster Steffens stated
the existence of a "woman
seeking and fulfilling her own
desires" while the replacement
was one of a "woman abused
by the roles of wife, mother,
and servant." They are, says
Steffens, "opposite ends of the
same continuum."
The Writing Seminars Department does not intend to
change its procedures by
previewing posters for advertisement, said AreIlan°. In fact
if the original poster had not
mentioned the Writing Seminars Department, AreIlan° said,
the complaints would have been
Steffens' problem alone. Steffens plans to follow the case
through the campus channels
and even mentioned the
possibility of producing a Tshirt.

David Creagh:The Man Controlling 10K Watts
When David Creugh was hired
to manage WJHU he may not
lame realized the long and tortuous road that would finally
allow the station to broadcast
at at 10,000 watts. In an interview held eight hours after the
.power boost occured,Creagh
(IF cc
the station, itsfanner
problems. and itsjUture hopes.
Q:Today was your first day
on the air at 10,000 watts, did
everything run smoothly or
were there any unexpected
problems?
A: No, it ran rather more
smoothly on the first day than
I expected. The one single advantage of the FCC delay was
that it gave us time to get our
operations down and practice.
We've been operating a music
schedule on the 10 watt station
for about ten weeks, so the announcers were right up to speed
and familiar to the equipment
so the transition was not really
difficult.
A little snag here and there.
A traffic report came in late, or
we would read the time wrong,
people getting used to clocks,
but I was amazed and pleased
at how smooth it was.
Q: The FCC did not grant
the authorization for the boost
until weeks after the station was
ready, did this disappoint you
at all?
A: You bet. Absolutely
disappointed me. We've got 20
sc ho are hired to run a radio
station, and whereas it was
useful to spend time planning,
part icularily on air people were
going a little crazy. I didn't
come here to Hopkins to plan
a radio station, I came here to
manage one, and we haven't
had a station to Manage until 36
hours ago. Feels real good, real
good. I was once quoted as
having said it's like getting all
dressed up and having no place
to go. It was terrible, terrible
Frustration, because the FCC
delayed it so. Finally Saturday
we got a telegram giving us the
authority, so we're off. Or
we're on.
Q: What reasons did the
FCC give for their delay in
granting authorization for the
boost?
A: The FCC does not give
reasons. They're not required
to.
I know what the reasons were
Ii om our attorneys. This is a little complicated. There is a
license for a station for our
same frequency in Frederick,.
Maryland owned by a group of
fundamentalist Christians. It's
called the Joy Public Broadcasting Corporation.
'I-hey have been very sloppy
with their FCC license and a
couple of times they have failed to renew their FCC license.
It expired and nothing
happened.
At one point we made the
determination that because
their construction permit had
expired, that they were gone.
'This happens a lot with Christian groups in radio. They have
a great idea to build a station,
but they fail to get the funding
so they just collapse. We figured since they missed the
deadline they were gone.

So we proposed to the FCC
a very large coverage area with
expanded coverage pointed
towards Frederick since there
was no station there that we
would have to protect. Then
two months later, after we filed our paperwork, the FCC
suprised us by renewing the
license application of the Christian group, which meant that
we had to completely modify all
our engineering.
In other words, we had to go
back to square one. We had to
redefine our coverage area based on extremely limited coverage in the western direction,
which we did.
We didn't get that filed with
the commision until June
because we didn't learn until
the last part of May, that the
FCC had acted the way they did
on the Frederick station. So
that cost a whole month of
backlog.
Our original construction
permit was filed in January and
would have probably been accepted in March. We could
have been on in April or May.
'In one sentence, the FCC
surprised us in approving a 88.1
station in Frederick that caused all our engineering plans to
go down the tubes, so we had
to start all over in June, and it
was that June application
which was not approved by the
FCC until October.
Approval occured on Friday,
notification occurred on Saturday, and we were on the air
Monday night. Q: When you were hired by.
the University, what was the
deadline for getting the station
on the air, and why was it then
necesary to request extensions
of the construction permit?
A: I did not get a specific
deadline from the University, it
was just to generally get the station on as as soon as possible.
My original plan was to try to
get the station on this spring,
which satisfied the University.
It was necessary to request
extensions of our original construction permit, because prior
to my arrival the plan was to
build a tower on the Homewood campus. In fact, prior to
my arrival, there was a valid
construction permit for a
25,000 watt station operating
from a 250 foot tower on the
Homewood campus.
The engineers in the space
telescope
institute
and
elsewhere on campus became
suddenly very fearful of 25,000
watts, and rightfully so. That's
lots of raw power right there on
the campus. If I were in that
situation, and made my living
based on a lot of scientific
research I would not want that
much power to screw up the
readings on my instruments.
Nobody foresaw this before I
got here. The first thing I had
to do when I arrived was to find
a different tower location that
was not on the campus.
To find a new tower took
about six weeks. Once you find
a tower, you have to negotiate
a lease with the tower company
and then you have to change all
your engineering work, because
the amount of power that you
have in different directions

depends on were the tower is,
because you're moving closer to
or farther away from stations
on nearby frequencies that you
have to protect. The reason for
the need of FCC extension was
because the original concept of
growing out of the student station was to operate 25,000
watts on Homewood. That was
unworkable. My first job was
to fix that problem; find
another tower.
The tradeoff of height versus
power let us go down to 10,000
watts with the new tower.
It has worked to our advantage.
There are two important factors that determine the distance
that the signal travels, height
and transmitter power. We are
now located on Park Heights,
the highest spot of land in the
city of Baltimore. That puts us
about 2(X) feet higher than we
would have if we remained at
Homewood. That additional
200 feet of height required us to
lower our power to 10,000
watts. Even with the reduced
power, it is not a net savings
since we are paying many thousands of dollars a year for the
lease of the tower.
Q: WJHU will be competing
with other Baltimore stations
that broadcast classical and jazz
music. What advantages if any
does WJHU have that over
these stations, and how does it
plan to increase its advantage.?
A: We have three main advantages over WBJC. T-he first
is that we are a full service station. They have decided to narrow their programming to just
classical music. We offer
significant amounts of national
and international news, commentary, features from National Public Radio as well as local
news and information, traffic
reports, sports and weather.
People don't spend their
whole lives in concert halls.
Neither do people listen to
classical music around the
clock. So, number one, we'll be
a full service approach. I'd say
that number two, our music
programming will be more diverse. We have a larger collection of compact discs than
WBJC and our musical tastes
will be more varied, while they
seem to be very conservative.
They stick to the same sixty or
eighty albums all the time. We
will have much more musical
diversity in our programming.
The third advantage that we
have is our announcing staff
which I believe is the best in the
country.
Q: I noticed ,from your program guide that you are airing
programs such as 'All Things
Considered' and 'Morning Addition' that used to be aired on
WBJC. Are they planning to
continue running these
programs?
A: They are for the time being. Those programs are
available from NPR to anyone
who wants to buy them.
They're very, very expensive.
WBJC has made the decision to
cancel its membership as of
December I.
The station WEAA at
Morgan State University has
maintained its NPR membership, but does not regularly

head of public relations went

programming.

classical music field. A classical
music station already services
the Baltimore area: W.IBC.
Asked what tactics would be used to help WJHU compete with
its already well-established
competitor, Zacharias replied,
"No tactics. We are different."

wattage, an advertising camFile Photo

"several other groups," including the SAC.
But, for the moment,
Hopkins has only one radio station.

How Not to Expand
A Radio Station
The lower end of the FM dial got a jolt
early Tuesday morning—a 10,000 watt
jolt--as a massive power boost ushered
in a new era for WJHU. With the boost
came the end of a long and drawn-out
station expansion which has been igniting
controversy on campus for over two and
a half years.
To recap a story which by now must
be familiar to almost everyone, in March
of 1984, University President Steven
Muller wrote to the Federal Communication Commission to announce the
University's intention to shut down the
old student-run 10 watt WJHU and
replace it with a new professionally
managed 25,000 watt station "by the
first of July [19841 or soon thereafter."
(The plans for 25,000 watts were later
reduced to 10,000 when a new antenna
site was chosen that required less wattage
for the same listener area.)
At the time, the student operated
WJHU had been chosen by The
Baltimore Magazine as the best station
in Baltimore.
Two and a half years and countless
1.( '( • liek.sn,c c\ tt.snion \ later. the station
Finally boosted power this week broadcasting under the leadership of professional station manager David Creagh.
To be sure, the newly expanded station seems headed for success. With a
Full-time professional news team, experienced DJ's, an innovative format of
classics and jazz (under-represented in
the Baltimore radio market), and sudden
access to potential listeners as far away
as Pennsylvania, it would be difficult for
the station to go wrong.
But while the future of the new station
seems bright, its recent past has been a
dark blight on the administration of this
U niversity.
In the wake of the University's less
than electrifying planning of the station's
power boost, perhaps a few things can
be learned. First, in planning a project,
particularly a technical one, discussion
with technical advisors from the earliest
moments of project planning needs to
take place. Creagh has continually maintained that do eloping a station like the

new WJHU takes a least a year and a
half to two years to complete. His projection seems reasonable. Why then was
the University community told initially
that the entire process would take only
three months? Either a lack of' technical
consultation or complete disregard for
technical advice must have been at work.
Secondly, planning of projects like the
power boost needs to begin early. In the
case of WJHU, it's clear that the administration dawdled much too long in
the early stages of the project. David
Creagh was hired more than a year afterthe professionally managed station was
originally scheduled to return to the air
and a permanent site for the station's office wasn't found until many months
later. A university like Hopkins which
has experience attracting leaders in many
fields ought to have realized that a
"talent search" for a top-notch general
manager could not happen overnight.
Finally, in planning a project like
WJHU,the University needs to be much
more attuned and sensitive to students.
Certainly, the original termination of
WJ HU's broadcasts in 1984 had to have
been one of the most callous moves the
administration has made in recent years.
The student operators of the awardwinning station were given exactly five
days of advance warning that their station would be shut down in preparation
for the development of a new professionally managed WJHU.
When plans call for the elimination of
a successful and prospering student
organization, like the old WJHU, the
students involved ought to be allowed to
participate in planning discussions—not
simply told what will happen.
With the power boost now history,
reflecting on what should have happenH is a hit ()I a moot point Hopefully,
though, the administration will reassess
its mistakes in the WJHU power boost
and ensure that they don't happen again.
If nothing else, though, the recent planning for WJHU has at least shown the
community how not to expand a radio
station.

Those Raucous Seals
Every spring brings the raucous return
of the S.A.C. Seals to our campus. But
hopefully this year, the awards will find
themselves on the endangered species list.
For those new to Hopkins' rite of
spring, the Student Activities Commission Seals are awards given to graduating
seniors to recognize outstanding leadership or participation in extracurricular
activities. According to a recently
reformed selection procedure, the Executive Committee of the S.A.C. draws
up a list of seniors(up to five percent of
the graduating class) to receive the
award. The Exec. Board's list must be
approved by both the S.A.C. and the
Student Council.
In principle, of course, the idea is a
good one. It's always pleasant to
recognize those students who go out of

their way to make Hopkins a more enjoyable (and less overwhelmingly
academic) place. But in practice, the
S.A.C. Seals are anything but pleasant.
Last year (and most years), approving
a list of S.A.C. seal recipients has
degenerated into a free-for-all showing
Council members at their nastiest.
This year, discussions are already
underway to reform the Seals. We have
a simple suggestion—eliminate them.
No one wants to see the last days of
senior year spoiled with childish and ugly
name-calling as they inevitably have been
in the past. A much wiser and happier
alternative for everyone involved would
be to forget about the awards. The
S.A.C. awards are one species of seals
that certainly shouldn't be saved.

Extra Job Pitfalls
To the Editor:
The apartheid issue at
Hopkins has been characterized by a great deal of friction beteen students (and some professors) and the school administrators over the issue of
investments in South Africa. As
important as the issue is, I want
to discuss the people involved;
chiefly, the students. In the
course of lobbying and protesting, the students involved
have begun to alienate the
students not actively involved.
On October sixth, Maryland
National Bank held a gathering
for all students interested in applying for jobs in their company. This event, which is a
MNB first at Hopkins, was
designed to help the students
applying for jobs there by offering information about the
company, giving tips about
how to interview with MNB,
and giving the students a
chance to meet the people who

run MNB.
I was invited to this gathering since I am planning to interview with MNB. I was
shocked, outraged and mostly
embarrassed when the apartheid protesters showed up at
the gathering. The protesters
surrounded the Glass Pavilion
(the site of the gathering). They
waved banners around, waved
their hands at the people inside,
made noises, and distributed
leaflets inside all in an effort to
distract and disrupt the gathering(even if this was not their in:
tention, it was the result). All of
these distractions made it very
difficult to carry on conversations and made everyone feel
unnecessarily uncomfortable.
In addition, I do not think this
type of behavior left very good
impressions, in our host's
minds, of the type of student
that goes to Hopkins. MNB
probably won't hire people that
are opposed to their investments(the protesters claimed that MNB had financial interests in Soth Africa; at least
that is what their posters claimed) therefore the Hopkins student has lost some credibility
with this bank, because of the
protesting going on around the
gathering. Further, the verbal
harrassment that the protesters
gave us, upon departure from
the gathering, was unncessary.
I don't need to hear sarcastic
comments like, "Yeah, he'll
probably go far in life."
I would hope that in the
future the protesters could
show a little more courtesy to
the other students. This includes not hindering the job
search effort of students by
alienation of corporations offering jobs (finding a job is
hard enough without creating
extra pitfalls) and not harrassing students who do not want
to participate in the antiapartheid movement. These are
courtesies which should be
granted. Otherwise the protesters may find that they are
fighting more than our school's
Trustees.
Steven C. Schiller

With a small knife, cut all the way around the

"The world is more wonderful than useful, more beautiful
than convenient," quoted
Baltimore Sun feature writer
Isaac Rehart from the Walden
Pond writings of Thoreau in
the former's opening remarks
at last week's installment of the
Wednesday Noon Lecture
Series.
Rehart, a 26 year veteran of
the Sun and a graduate of the
Hopkins Writing Seminars,
shared his feelings about
newspaper
writing
and
Baltimore with a mainly elderly audience. An avid reader of
Thoreau from youth, Rehart
shared the former's sense of
detachment from the sharper
edges of society, commenting
that if "these people [The Sun]
knew who I was, they'd fire
me."
Beginning as a police
reporter for the Sun in 1960,

Rehart grew weary of covering
the criminal side of Baltimore.
Wanting to write more freely,
he was told to "write his way
out" by various mentors at the
Sun. A successful story about
a duck from his farm propelled Rehart from crime reporting
to the obituaries, and then on
to features.
"No subject," said Rehart,
"is too big for the feature page.
The only requirement is that the
story fits," gesticulating a rectangle with his hands," in a certain size of box." In search of
subjects for his articles, Rehart
wandered around Baltimore
getting to know residents and
establishing a rapport with local
characters. Rehart told of a
fellow he found tending a
garden on the edge of the then
filthy and slum-like Inner Harbor, tending pet praying manti.
A point Rehart emphasized
when dealing with local
characters was "do not rein-

force negative stereotypes, e‘en
if they apply." Recalling one of
his efforts to show the effects
of the then-new Francis Scott
Key Bridge from a local
perspective years ago, Rehart
said that such stereotyping can
be "humiliating and insulting
to the subject."
In its day-to-day contact with
people, Rehart sees newspapers
as "the most humanizing element in a democratic society.
I'm glad to be a feature writer,
features being the most human
part of the newspaper." In
pointing out the impact of
newspapers on society in the
1980's, Rehart points out that
he is amazed by "how incredibly opinionated everyone
is." Such availability of information via newspapers makes
newspaper's role as "a conscience, the meditative side of
society" that much more
important.

"Peggy Sue": Time Traveling Prom Queen
by Meg Burns
"If you could do it all again,
would you do anything differently?" Peggy Sue answers
emphatically yes. At her 25th
high school reunion she is looking at divorcing her husband of
25 years, Crazy Charlie the Appliance King (Nicolas Cage).
When she is elected Reunion
Queen with Richard Norvuck
(Barry Miller), former class
geek turned millionaire, and
suddenly sees Charlie, whom
she had hoped to avoid, between the excitement of the one
and strain of the other she collapses. When she awakens, she is
told she fainted while giving
blood—in the spring blood
drive of 1960.
The whole premise of
"Peggy Sue Got Married" —
time travel— requites a certain
suspension of disbelief, and for
most of the movie that suspension is not difficult to maintain.
The movie's only real joke is
very funny, and the writers
milk it for all it's worth, but by
the end of the movie the I'm going-to-act-like-a-42-year-oldeven-if-you-think -I'm -18
business begins to irritate. The
device for returning her to 1986
also irritates, as it is impossibly
contrived. Disbelief can only be
suspended so far, but as this is
the only real failing of the

movie a liberal reviewer is willing to forgive it.
For those of you who worry
about time paradoxes and inadvertantly rewriting history,
our writers have avoided that.
Although Peggy Sue says she'd
do it all differently, she actually makes only minor and in the
end insignificant changes; the
crucial decisions which have led
up to where she is at her 25th
reunion remain the same, even
though she does "know then
what she knew now."
Kathleen Turner looks a bit
young for 42 but obviously enjoys the part. One would think
someone in her position would
be a bit more self-conscious
about doing 1986 things in
1960, but it's all to further the
purpose of the movie and its
one joke, and it is tremendously funny. Nicolas Cage is better at eighteen than at fortythree, but fortunately is only on
screen a very few minutes in the
older role. He is very convincing as the fairly airheaded and
immature, but basically goodhearted boy-next-door, who is
utterly confused by the change
that's come over Peggy Sue in
the last few days. Overall the
supporting cast makes the transition smoothly, helping to propel the movie toward a conclusion which is satisfying without
being happy-sappy.

David Creagh:The Man Controlling 10K Watts
When David Creugh was hired
to manage WJHU he may not
lame realized the long and tortuous road that would finally
allow the station to broadcast
at at 10,000 watts. In an interview held eight hours after the
.power boost occured,Creagh
(IF cc
the station, itsfanner
problems. and itsjUture hopes.
Q:Today was your first day
on the air at 10,000 watts, did
everything run smoothly or
were there any unexpected
problems?
A: No, it ran rather more
smoothly on the first day than
I expected. The one single advantage of the FCC delay was
that it gave us time to get our
operations down and practice.
We've been operating a music
schedule on the 10 watt station
for about ten weeks, so the announcers were right up to speed
and familiar to the equipment
so the transition was not really
difficult.
A little snag here and there.
A traffic report came in late, or
we would read the time wrong,
people getting used to clocks,
but I was amazed and pleased
at how smooth it was.
Q: The FCC did not grant
the authorization for the boost
until weeks after the station was
ready, did this disappoint you
at all?
A: You bet. Absolutely
disappointed me. We've got 20
sc ho are hired to run a radio
station, and whereas it was
useful to spend time planning,
part icularily on air people were
going a little crazy. I didn't
come here to Hopkins to plan
a radio station, I came here to
manage one, and we haven't
had a station to Manage until 36
hours ago. Feels real good, real
good. I was once quoted as
having said it's like getting all
dressed up and having no place
to go. It was terrible, terrible
Frustration, because the FCC
delayed it so. Finally Saturday
we got a telegram giving us the
authority, so we're off. Or
we're on.
Q: What reasons did the
FCC give for their delay in
granting authorization for the
boost?
A: The FCC does not give
reasons. They're not required
to.
I know what the reasons were
Ii om our attorneys. This is a little complicated. There is a
license for a station for our
same frequency in Frederick,.
Maryland owned by a group of
fundamentalist Christians. It's
called the Joy Public Broadcasting Corporation.
'I-hey have been very sloppy
with their FCC license and a
couple of times they have failed to renew their FCC license.
It expired and nothing
happened.
At one point we made the
determination that because
their construction permit had
expired, that they were gone.
'This happens a lot with Christian groups in radio. They have
a great idea to build a station,
but they fail to get the funding
so they just collapse. We figured since they missed the
deadline they were gone.

So we proposed to the FCC
a very large coverage area with
expanded coverage pointed
towards Frederick since there
was no station there that we
would have to protect. Then
two months later, after we filed our paperwork, the FCC
suprised us by renewing the
license application of the Christian group, which meant that
we had to completely modify all
our engineering.
In other words, we had to go
back to square one. We had to
redefine our coverage area based on extremely limited coverage in the western direction,
which we did.
We didn't get that filed with
the commision until June
because we didn't learn until
the last part of May, that the
FCC had acted the way they did
on the Frederick station. So
that cost a whole month of
backlog.
Our original construction
permit was filed in January and
would have probably been accepted in March. We could
have been on in April or May.
'In one sentence, the FCC
surprised us in approving a 88.1
station in Frederick that caused all our engineering plans to
go down the tubes, so we had
to start all over in June, and it
was that June application
which was not approved by the
FCC until October.
Approval occured on Friday,
notification occurred on Saturday, and we were on the air
Monday night. Q: When you were hired by.
the University, what was the
deadline for getting the station
on the air, and why was it then
necesary to request extensions
of the construction permit?
A: I did not get a specific
deadline from the University, it
was just to generally get the station on as as soon as possible.
My original plan was to try to
get the station on this spring,
which satisfied the University.
It was necessary to request
extensions of our original construction permit, because prior
to my arrival the plan was to
build a tower on the Homewood campus. In fact, prior to
my arrival, there was a valid
construction permit for a
25,000 watt station operating
from a 250 foot tower on the
Homewood campus.
The engineers in the space
telescope
institute
and
elsewhere on campus became
suddenly very fearful of 25,000
watts, and rightfully so. That's
lots of raw power right there on
the campus. If I were in that
situation, and made my living
based on a lot of scientific
research I would not want that
much power to screw up the
readings on my instruments.
Nobody foresaw this before I
got here. The first thing I had
to do when I arrived was to find
a different tower location that
was not on the campus.
To find a new tower took
about six weeks. Once you find
a tower, you have to negotiate
a lease with the tower company
and then you have to change all
your engineering work, because
the amount of power that you
have in different directions

depends on were the tower is,
because you're moving closer to
or farther away from stations
on nearby frequencies that you
have to protect. The reason for
the need of FCC extension was
because the original concept of
growing out of the student station was to operate 25,000
watts on Homewood. That was
unworkable. My first job was
to fix that problem; find
another tower.
The tradeoff of height versus
power let us go down to 10,000
watts with the new tower.
It has worked to our advantage.
There are two important factors that determine the distance
that the signal travels, height
and transmitter power. We are
now located on Park Heights,
the highest spot of land in the
city of Baltimore. That puts us
about 2(X) feet higher than we
would have if we remained at
Homewood. That additional
200 feet of height required us to
lower our power to 10,000
watts. Even with the reduced
power, it is not a net savings
since we are paying many thousands of dollars a year for the
lease of the tower.
Q: WJHU will be competing
with other Baltimore stations
that broadcast classical and jazz
music. What advantages if any
does WJHU have that over
these stations, and how does it
plan to increase its advantage.?
A: We have three main advantages over WBJC. T-he first
is that we are a full service station. They have decided to narrow their programming to just
classical music. We offer
significant amounts of national
and international news, commentary, features from National Public Radio as well as local
news and information, traffic
reports, sports and weather.
People don't spend their
whole lives in concert halls.
Neither do people listen to
classical music around the
clock. So, number one, we'll be
a full service approach. I'd say
that number two, our music
programming will be more diverse. We have a larger collection of compact discs than
WBJC and our musical tastes
will be more varied, while they
seem to be very conservative.
They stick to the same sixty or
eighty albums all the time. We
will have much more musical
diversity in our programming.
The third advantage that we
have is our announcing staff
which I believe is the best in the
country.
Q: I noticed ,from your program guide that you are airing
programs such as 'All Things
Considered' and 'Morning Addition' that used to be aired on
WBJC. Are they planning to
continue running these
programs?
A: They are for the time being. Those programs are
available from NPR to anyone
who wants to buy them.
They're very, very expensive.
WBJC has made the decision to
cancel its membership as of
December I.
The station WEAA at
Morgan State University has
maintained its NPR membership, but does not regularly

week employment. Right now

for her work .here with the
writing seminars department.
One is an announcer. One is
a Peabody student and is working in music cataloguing. One
student is an engineer. He is
now a grad student at Hopkins.
Right now I am looking, and
would be delighted to find four
or five people who would be interested in learning to operate
our very sophisticated digital

recording equipment, to help
out with music recordings and
do regular board operations
here in the afternoon, and on
Sundays. We would not be able
to pay them, but it's a tremendous learning opprtunity.

production skills or some
technical background and interested should get in touch
with me right away. I would try

come forward, becuase it's a
very decentralized campus.

will be before the station is
totally self sufficient?

totally self sufficient. A university station which has to pay
real rent for its facilities, real
phone bills, real postage, real
power usage, can never be
totally self sufficient.
It is our intention to be largely self-sufficient at the end of
our third full year of operation.
I have not defined what 'largely self-sufficient' means, but I
expect that we will be raising at
least two-thirds of our income,
from non-University sources.
Q: How do you think the
broadcast of Hopkins lacrosse
games in the spring will effect

it would be a bad idea. I am
convinced that broadcasting

On the other hand, as the
manager of a university radio
station, I sometimes have to
take the broader interests of the

University wants very much for

anyone ever had, and we'll

music station already services

Hopkins has only one radio station.

How Not to Expand
A Radio Station
The lower end of the FM dial got a jolt
early Tuesday morning—a 10,000 watt
jolt--as a massive power boost ushered
in a new era for WJHU. With the boost
came the end of a long and drawn-out
station expansion which has been igniting
controversy on campus for over two and
a half years.
To recap a story which by now must
be familiar to almost everyone, in March
of 1984, University President Steven
Muller wrote to the Federal Communication Commission to announce the
University's intention to shut down the
old student-run 10 watt WJHU and
replace it with a new professionally
managed 25,000 watt station "by the
first of July [19841 or soon thereafter."
(The plans for 25,000 watts were later
reduced to 10,000 when a new antenna
site was chosen that required less wattage
for the same listener area.)
At the time, the student operated
WJHU had been chosen by The
Baltimore Magazine as the best station
in Baltimore.
Two and a half years and countless
1.( '( • liek.sn,c c\ tt.snion \ later. the station
Finally boosted power this week broadcasting under the leadership of professional station manager David Creagh.
To be sure, the newly expanded station seems headed for success. With a
Full-time professional news team, experienced DJ's, an innovative format of
classics and jazz (under-represented in
the Baltimore radio market), and sudden
access to potential listeners as far away
as Pennsylvania, it would be difficult for
the station to go wrong.
But while the future of the new station
seems bright, its recent past has been a
dark blight on the administration of this
U niversity.
In the wake of the University's less
than electrifying planning of the station's
power boost, perhaps a few things can
be learned. First, in planning a project,
particularly a technical one, discussion
with technical advisors from the earliest
moments of project planning needs to
take place. Creagh has continually maintained that do eloping a station like the

new WJHU takes a least a year and a
half to two years to complete. His projection seems reasonable. Why then was
the University community told initially
that the entire process would take only
three months? Either a lack of' technical
consultation or complete disregard for
technical advice must have been at work.
Secondly, planning of projects like the
power boost needs to begin early. In the
case of WJHU, it's clear that the administration dawdled much too long in
the early stages of the project. David
Creagh was hired more than a year afterthe professionally managed station was
originally scheduled to return to the air
and a permanent site for the station's office wasn't found until many months
later. A university like Hopkins which
has experience attracting leaders in many
fields ought to have realized that a
"talent search" for a top-notch general
manager could not happen overnight.
Finally, in planning a project like
WJHU,the University needs to be much
more attuned and sensitive to students.
Certainly, the original termination of
WJ HU's broadcasts in 1984 had to have
been one of the most callous moves the
administration has made in recent years.
The student operators of the awardwinning station were given exactly five
days of advance warning that their station would be shut down in preparation
for the development of a new professionally managed WJHU.
When plans call for the elimination of
a successful and prospering student
organization, like the old WJHU, the
students involved ought to be allowed to
participate in planning discussions—not
simply told what will happen.
With the power boost now history,
reflecting on what should have happenH is a hit ()I a moot point Hopefully,
though, the administration will reassess
its mistakes in the WJHU power boost
and ensure that they don't happen again.
If nothing else, though, the recent planning for WJHU has at least shown the
community how not to expand a radio
station.

Those Raucous Seals
Every spring brings the raucous return
of the S.A.C. Seals to our campus. But
hopefully this year, the awards will find
themselves on the endangered species list.
For those new to Hopkins' rite of
spring, the Student Activities Commission Seals are awards given to graduating
seniors to recognize outstanding leadership or participation in extracurricular
activities. According to a recently
reformed selection procedure, the Executive Committee of the S.A.C. draws
up a list of seniors(up to five percent of
the graduating class) to receive the
award. The Exec. Board's list must be
approved by both the S.A.C. and the
Student Council.
In principle, of course, the idea is a
good one. It's always pleasant to
recognize those students who go out of

their way to make Hopkins a more enjoyable (and less overwhelmingly
academic) place. But in practice, the
S.A.C. Seals are anything but pleasant.
Last year (and most years), approving
a list of S.A.C. seal recipients has
degenerated into a free-for-all showing
Council members at their nastiest.
This year, discussions are already
underway to reform the Seals. We have
a simple suggestion—eliminate them.
No one wants to see the last days of
senior year spoiled with childish and ugly
name-calling as they inevitably have been
in the past. A much wiser and happier
alternative for everyone involved would
be to forget about the awards. The
S.A.C. awards are one species of seals
that certainly shouldn't be saved.

Extra Job Pitfalls
To the Editor:
The apartheid issue at
Hopkins has been characterized by a great deal of friction beteen students (and some professors) and the school administrators over the issue of
investments in South Africa. As
important as the issue is, I want
to discuss the people involved;
chiefly, the students. In the
course of lobbying and protesting, the students involved
have begun to alienate the
students not actively involved.
On October sixth, Maryland
National Bank held a gathering
for all students interested in applying for jobs in their company. This event, which is a
MNB first at Hopkins, was
designed to help the students
applying for jobs there by offering information about the
company, giving tips about
how to interview with MNB,
and giving the students a
chance to meet the people who

run MNB.
I was invited to this gathering since I am planning to interview with MNB. I was
shocked, outraged and mostly
embarrassed when the apartheid protesters showed up at
the gathering. The protesters
surrounded the Glass Pavilion
(the site of the gathering). They
waved banners around, waved
their hands at the people inside,
made noises, and distributed
leaflets inside all in an effort to
distract and disrupt the gathering(even if this was not their in:
tention, it was the result). All of
these distractions made it very
difficult to carry on conversations and made everyone feel
unnecessarily uncomfortable.
In addition, I do not think this
type of behavior left very good
impressions, in our host's
minds, of the type of student
that goes to Hopkins. MNB
probably won't hire people that
are opposed to their investments(the protesters claimed that MNB had financial interests in Soth Africa; at least
that is what their posters claimed) therefore the Hopkins student has lost some credibility
with this bank, because of the
protesting going on around the
gathering. Further, the verbal
harrassment that the protesters
gave us, upon departure from
the gathering, was unncessary.
I don't need to hear sarcastic
comments like, "Yeah, he'll
probably go far in life."
I would hope that in the
future the protesters could
show a little more courtesy to
the other students. This includes not hindering the job
search effort of students by
alienation of corporations offering jobs (finding a job is
hard enough without creating
extra pitfalls) and not harrassing students who do not want
to participate in the antiapartheid movement. These are
courtesies which should be
granted. Otherwise the protesters may find that they are
fighting more than our school's
Trustees.
Steven C. Schiller

"The world is more wonderful than useful, more beautiful
than convenient," quoted
Baltimore Sun feature writer
Isaac Rehart from the Walden
Pond writings of Thoreau in
the former's opening remarks
at last week's installment of the
Wednesday Noon Lecture
Series.
Rehart, a 26 year veteran of
the Sun and a graduate of the
Hopkins Writing Seminars,
shared his feelings about
newspaper
writing
and
Baltimore with a mainly elderly audience. An avid reader of
Thoreau from youth, Rehart
shared the former's sense of
detachment from the sharper
edges of society, commenting
that if "these people [The Sun]
knew who I was, they'd fire
me."
Beginning as a police
reporter for the Sun in 1960,

Rehart grew weary of covering
the criminal side of Baltimore.
Wanting to write more freely,
he was told to "write his way
out" by various mentors at the
Sun. A successful story about
a duck from his farm propelled Rehart from crime reporting
to the obituaries, and then on
to features.
"No subject," said Rehart,
"is too big for the feature page.
The only requirement is that the
story fits," gesticulating a rectangle with his hands," in a certain size of box." In search of
subjects for his articles, Rehart
wandered around Baltimore
getting to know residents and
establishing a rapport with local
characters. Rehart told of a
fellow he found tending a
garden on the edge of the then
filthy and slum-like Inner Harbor, tending pet praying manti.
A point Rehart emphasized
when dealing with local
characters was "do not rein-

force negative stereotypes, e‘en
if they apply." Recalling one of
his efforts to show the effects
of the then-new Francis Scott
Key Bridge from a local
perspective years ago, Rehart
said that such stereotyping can
be "humiliating and insulting
to the subject."
In its day-to-day contact with
people, Rehart sees newspapers
as "the most humanizing element in a democratic society.
I'm glad to be a feature writer,
features being the most human
part of the newspaper." In
pointing out the impact of
newspapers on society in the
1980's, Rehart points out that
he is amazed by "how incredibly opinionated everyone
is." Such availability of information via newspapers makes
newspaper's role as "a conscience, the meditative side of
society" that much more
important.

by Meg Burns
"If you could do it all again,
would you do anything differently?" Peggy Sue answers
emphatically yes. At her 25th
high school reunion she is looking at divorcing her husband of

When she is elected Reunion
Queen with Richard Norvuck
(Barry Miller), former class
geek turned millionaire, and
suddenly sees Charlie, whom
she had hoped to avoid, between the excitement of the one
and strain of the other she collapses. When she awakens, she is
told she fainted while giving
blood—in the spring blood
drive of 1960.
The whole premise of
"Peggy Sue Got Married" —
time travel— requites a certain
suspension of disbelief, and for
most of the movie that suspension is not difficult to maintain.
The movie's only real joke is
very funny, and the writers
milk it for all it's worth, but by
the end of the movie the I'm going-to-act-like-a-42-year-oldeven-if-you-think -I'm -18
business begins to irritate. The
device for returning her to 1986
also irritates, as it is impossibly
contrived. Disbelief can only be
suspended so far, but as this is
the only real failing of the

movie a liberal reviewer is willing to forgive it.
For those of you who worry
about time paradoxes and inadvertantly rewriting history,
our writers have avoided that.
Although Peggy Sue says she'd
do it all differently, she actually makes only minor and in the
end insignificant changes; the
crucial decisions which have led
up to where she is at her 25th
reunion remain the same, even
though she does "know then
what she knew now."
Kathleen Turner looks a bit
young for 42 but obviously enjoys the part. One would think
someone in her position would
be a bit more self-conscious
about doing 1986 things in
1960, but it's all to further the
purpose of the movie and its
one joke, and it is tremendously funny. Nicolas Cage is better at eighteen than at fortythree, but fortunately is only on
screen a very few minutes in the
older role. He is very convincing as the fairly airheaded and
immature, but basically goodhearted boy-next-door, who is
utterly confused by the change
that's come over Peggy Sue in
the last few days. Overall the
supporting cast makes the transition smoothly, helping to propel the movie toward a conclusion which is satisfying without
being happy-sappy.
